channel.title: Daily Feed (Updated 9 AM BD)
channel.description: Daily Feed (Updated 9 AM BD) generated by script

item.title: Money Matters: US Congress passes $50B foreign affairs bill into law
item.description: The bill’s passage marks a major milestone, but it also raises new questions. Plus, who got the most foreign aid in 2024, and a new fund that revives USAID’s Development Innovation Ventures — this time, outside of government.

item.title: Local Resilience Can Mitigate Climate Conflicts in the Pacific
item.description: The Pacific Island countries are at the frontline of climate change. Their territories mostly consist of small, low-lying islands, with long coastlines and vast ocean spaces between them. Many livelihoods are based on agriculture or fishing, and importing water or food is often infeasible or expensive. This makes those large ocean nations highly vulnerable […]

item.title: A Business Necessity: Align With Nature or Risk Collapse, IPBES Report Warns
item.description: Business can still remain profitable while protecting the environment but invest in nature-positive operations, says a landmark report by the Intergovernmental Platform on Biodiversity and Ecosystem Services (IPBES), which finds that global companies have contributed to the escalating loss of biodiversity. The IPBES Methodological Assessment Report on the Impact and Dependence of Business on Biodiversity […]

item.title: ‘After Decades of Denial and Silence, the Suffering of Rohingya People Is Being Heard at the World’s Highest Court’
item.description: CIVICUS discusses the genocide case against Myanmar at the International Court of Justice (ICJ) with Mohammed Nowkhim of the Arakan Rohingya Society for Peace & Human Rights (ARSPHR), a civil society organisation led by Rohingya people born out of refugee camps in Bangladesh to document atrocities, preserve survivor testimony and advocate for accountability and […]

item.title: Devex Newswire: What's next for World Bank without its '$700 billion man'
item.description: A look at the leaders of the World Bank and the World Health Organization.

item.title: 53 migrants die in latest shipwreck tragedy off Libya coast
item.description: Fifty-three migrants including two babies are dead or missing after a large rubber dinghy capsized off the coast of Libya, the UN migration agency said on Monday.

item.title: UN calls for release of Hong Kong publisher Jimmy Lai following 20-year sentence
item.description: The UN human rights chief on Monday called for the immediate release of Hong Kong media magnate Jimmy Lai after a Chinese court handed him a 20-year prison sentence under the city’s national security legislation, warning the verdict violates international human rights law.

item.title: Sudan: UN rights chief says worse is to come without international action
item.description: As the brutal Sudan war shows no signs of ending, UN human rights chief Volker Türk on Monday called on the international community to intervene immediately to stop more mass killings and other flagrant war crimes against civilians.

item.title: DR Congo: UN vows orderly peacekeeping transition as South Africa withdraws troops
item.description: South Africa has moved to withdraw its peacekeepers deployed at the United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in the Democratic Republic of the Congo (MONUSCO) after nearly three decades of service.

item.title: World News in Brief: Floods in Syria, relief operations in Cuba at risk, ending child labour
item.description: Severe flooding triggered by heavy rainfall has hit northwest Syria, killing two children and affecting more than 5,000 displaced people, the UN said on Monday.

item.title: West Bank: New Israeli measures further erode prospects for two-State solution
item.description: UN Secretary-General António Guterres voiced grave concern on Monday over the reported decision by the Israeli security cabinet to authorize a series of administrative and enforcement measures in Areas A and B in the occupied West Bank.

item.title: Does the development world needs to worry about critical minerals?
item.description: As demand for lithium, cobalt, and copper surges, mineral-rich countries are rewriting the rules on who controls the resources driving the clean energy transition. So, what are they?

item.title: Does the development world need to worry about critical minerals?
item.description: As demand for lithium, cobalt, and copper surges, mineral-rich countries are rewriting the rules on who controls the resources driving the clean energy transition. So, what are they?

item.title: Goal 1: End Poverty in all its Forms –Everywhere
item.description: Eradicating extreme poverty for all people everywhere by 2030 is a pivotal aim of the Sustainable Development Goals. Extreme poverty, defined as surviving on less than US$3.00 per person per day at 2021 purchasing power parity, has witnessed remarkable declines over recent decades. However, in 2025, 808 million people – or 1 in 10 people […]

item.title: ‘When Rains Come, Our Hearts Beat Faster’
item.description: A recent report reveals that Asia faces about 100 natural disasters every year, affecting 80 million people. Beyond the statistics are the disrupted lives, damaged homes, and a cycle of repair that drains communities.

item.title: Devex Pro Insider: Who made the Power 50 cut? Pro readers get the scoop
item.description: Check out the Devex Power 50 list — our newly released guide to individuals with increasing influence in the aid sector. Plus, the latest job moves in the sector.
